definition: Lord Guan (i.e. 關羽|关羽[Guan1 Yu3])
mountain pass/to close/to shut/to turn off/to concern/to involve
surname Guan

public/collectively owned/common/international (e.g. high seas, metric system, calendar)/make public/fair/just/Duke, highest of five orders of nobility 五等爵位[wu3 deng3 jue2 wei4]/honorable (gentlemen)/father-in-law/male (animal)
lit. to wield the broadsword in the presence of Lord Guan (idiom)/fig. to make a fool of oneself by showing off in front of an expert
pinyin: Guan1 gong1 mian4 qian2 shua3 da4 dao1

sentences.english: Opposite to the bench is Kwan Kung Temple.
sentences.chinese: 石櫈的对面，就是关公亭。

sentences.english: Most of the roles of Guan Yu on the opera stage are played in Kunqu.
sentences.chinese: 戏曲舞台上的关公戏，很多都是唱昆曲的。

sentences.english: Play a big knife before GuanGong.
The monk had someone served them first and walked Lord Guan to abbot's chamber.
sentences.chinese: 普净教取茶先奉夫人，然后请关公入方丈。

sentences.english: Cultural tourism and Guan Gong culture in Yuncheng area is inseparably interconnected.
sentences.chinese: 运城地区的文化旅游与关公文化是相辅相成的。

sentences.english: Lord Guan dismounted and extended the ritual courtesies.
By dawn Lord Guan and his commanders, waving flags and beating drums, were bearing down in large ships.
sentences.chinese: 比及平明，关公及众将皆摇旗鼓噪，乘大船而来。

sentences.english: In Guangzhou, there is a lane called "Duke Guan Lane".
sentences.chinese: 广州有一巷，名为“关公巷”。

sentences.english: The first large-scale original traditional drum show, Kuan Kung Waving Machetes.
sentences.chinese: 大型首创原创传统鼓乐名曲《关公舞刀》。

definition: courtesy name of 關羽|关羽[Guan1 Yu3]

Guan Yu (-219), general of Shu and blood-brother of Liu Bei in Romance of the Three Kingdoms, fearsome fighter famous for virtue and loyalty/posthumously worshipped and identified with the guardian Bodhisattva Sangharama
Oath of the Peach Garden, sworn by Liu Bei 劉備|刘备[Liu2 Bei4], Zhang Fei 張飛|张飞[Zhang1 Fei1] and Guan Yu 關羽|关羽[Guan1 Yu3] at the start of the Romance of Three Kingdoms 三國演義|三国演义[San1 guo2 Yan3 yi4]
courtesy name of Zhao Yun 趙雲|赵云[Zhao4 Yun2], general of Shu in Romance of the Three Kingdoms
ancient spear-like weapon 18 Chinese feet 尺[chi3] in length, with a wavy spearhead like a snake's body,
General Yuchi Gong (585-658), famous military man instrumental in founding the Tang dynasty
Marshal Zhao, aka Zhao Gongming or Zhao Xuantan, God of Wealth in the Chinese folk tradition and Taoism
to make a pact of brotherhood (from “Romance of the Three Kingdoms” 三國演義|三国演义[San1 guo2 Yan3 yi4]) (idiom)
Zhang Fei (168-221), general of Shu and blood-brother of Liu Bei in Romance of the Three Kingdoms, famous as fearsome fighter and lover of wine
to dramatize historical events/novel or play on historical theme
Zhao Gongming, God of Wealth in the Chinese folk tradition and Taoism
Luo Guanzhong (c. 1330-c. 1400), author of the Romance of the Three Kingdoms and other works

Romance of the Three Kingdoms by Luo Guanzhong 羅貫中|罗贯中[Luo2 Guan4 zhong1], one of the Four Classic Novels of Chinese literature/a fictional account of the Three Kingdoms at the break-up of the Han around 200 AD, consistently portraying Liu Bei's Shu Han 劉備|刘备, 蜀漢|蜀汉 as virtuous heroes and Cao Cao's Wei 曹操, 魏 as tyrannical villains
Zhao Yun (-229), general of Shu in Romance of the Three Kingdoms
loyal and righteous/fealty/loyalty
Erlangshen, Chinese deity
